metadata.titleEn: Geochemical data of major and trace elements of Lianyunshan pluton in northeastern Hunan Province
metadata.description: The main and micro test analysis of Lianyunshan rock mass was completed in Beijing Institute of geology of nuclear industry in 2019. X-ray fluorescence spectrometry (XRF) was used to determine the major elements. The process was as follows: first, 0.7G sample was weighed, and then boric acid was added to melt into glass at high temperature. Finally, the oxide content was determined by XRF (Philips pw2404 X-ray fluorescence spectrometer). The accuracy of major element analysis is better than 5% under the monitoring of gsr-1 (granite) standard sample. The determination of trace elements was carried out by ICP-MS: firstly, 50 mg sample was weighed and decomposed by hydrofluoric acid and nitric acid open container digestion method and hydrofluoric acid and nitric acid closed container digestion method, and the solution was made. Then, the internal standard method was used for determination on ICP-MS, and the analysis accuracy was better than 10%.
metadata.instructions: It is stored in word format, and the name of the file is "major and trace element". All files in the dataset can be opened directly in word

Verification.Question: Does the method of using X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) for major element analysis ensure an accuracy better than 5%?

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific characteristics of geochemical data collection methods used for analyzing major and trace elements in rock bodies?
Feature Specification.Answer: 0.7g sample, boric acid, glass melt, Philips PW2404 X-ray fluorescence spectrometer, analysis precision better than 5%, 50mg sample, hydrofluoric acid, nitric acid, internal standard method, ICP-MS, analysis precision better than 10%

Quantification.Question: What is the precision percentage of the major element analysis in a dataset using X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF)?

Definition.Question: What is the X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) method used for in the context of geochemical analysis of igneous rock bodies?
Definition.Answer: X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) is used for determining the major element content in igneous rock bodies. The method involves weighing 0.7g of the sample, adding an appropriate amount of boric acid to form a glass disk through high-temperature fusion, and then measuring the oxide content using a Philips PW2404 X-ray fluorescence spectrometer. The process ensures major element analysis precision is better than 5%.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the high precision required in the analysis of major and trace elements in geochemical data collection for rock bodies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The precision required in the analysis of major and trace elements in geochemical data collection is influenced by several factors. For major elements, the use of X-ray fluorescence spectrometry (XRF) with a specific instrument model (Philips PW2404) and the incorporation of control standards like GSR-1 (granite) ensure an accuracy of better than 5%. For trace elements, the combination of open and closed vessel decomposition methods using hydrofluoric acid and nitric acid, along with internal standard methods on ICP-MS, contributes to an accuracy of better than 10%.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of utilizing X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy and ICP-MS for geochemical analysis in the context of studying the major and trace elements of rock formations?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective of utilizing X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) for geochemical analysis in this context is to accurately determine the concentrations of major and trace elements within rock formations. The use of XRF allows for precise measurement of major element oxides, ensuring analysis precision better than 5%, while ICP-MS provides high-precision measurements of trace elements, maintaining an analysis precision better than 10%. This approach aims to provide detailed geochemical data that can contribute to understanding the composition, origin, and evolution of the rock formations in the region.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the instrumental and procedural steps involved in determining the major and trace elements in geological samples from the Lianyunshan pluton, and how do these methods ensure high analytical precision?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The major elements in geological samples from the Lianyunshan pluton are determined using X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF). The process involves weighing 0.7g of the sample, adding an appropriate amount of boric acid, and melting it at high temperature to form a glass disc. This glass disc is then analyzed using a Philips PW2404 model XRF spectrometer to measure oxide contents. The analysis is monitored using a GSR-1 granite standard to ensure that the precision of major element analysis is better than 5%. For trace elements, the samples are first weighed at 50mg and then decomposed using a combination of open and closed vessel methods with hydrofluoric and nitric acids. The resulting solution is analyzed using inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) with internal standards to achieve an analytical precision better than 10%.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the precise geochemical analysis of major and trace elements in geological samples from the Lianyunshan rock body?
Enablement.Answer: The use of X-ray fluorescence spectrometry (XRF) for major elements and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICPMS) for trace elements allows for precise geochemical analysis. The XRF method involves high-temperature fusion of samples with boric acid to form glass beads, which are then analyzed for oxide content using a Philips PW2404 XRF spectrometer, achieving accuracy better than 5%. For trace elements, samples are decomposed using both open and closed container methods with hydrofluoric acid and nitric acid, and measured using an internal standard method in ICP-MS, achieving an accuracy better than 10%.
